Name: Glycidol
Description: Glycidol is an epoxide and a primary alcohol. It is functionally related to a 1,2-epoxypropane.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Deneer JW et al; Aquat Toxicol 13: 195-204 (1988) (2) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.0. Jan, 2009. Available from, as of Oct 25, 2010: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF of 3 was calculated in fish for glycidol(SRC), using a log Kow of -0.95(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low(SRC).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval. Available from, as of Oct 25, 2010: https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html (2) Kaplan BL et al; Appl Environ Microbiol 43: 144-150 (1982)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Glycidol, present at 100 mg/L, reached 85% of its theoretical BOD in 4 weeks using an activated sludge inoculum at 30 mg/L in the Japanese MITI test(1). It was below the detection limit of 1 ppm after approximately 4 days at a test chemical concentration of 100 mg/L and added to an activated sludge inoculum in 250-ml Erlenmeyer shaker flasks incubated in both nutrient broth and basal salts media at 30 °C. When present as the sole source of carbon present, glycidol was below the detection limit after approximately 10 days(2).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Kaplan BL et al; Appl Environ Microbiol 43: 144 (1982)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: ANAEROBIC: Glycidol, present at 100 mg/L, was below the detection limit of 1 ppm after approximately 4 days using an activated sludge inoculum in 250-ml Erlenmeyer shaker flasks incubated in both nutrient broth and basal salts media at 37 °C. When present as the sole source of carbon present, glycidol was below the detection limit after approximately 10 days(1).

logP.References: Deneer JW et al; Aquat Toxicol 13: 195-204 (1988)

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Deneer JW et al; Aquat Toxicol 13: 195-204 (1988) (2) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.0. Jan, 2009. Available from, as of DATE: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm (3) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: The Koc of glycidol is estimated as 1(SRC), using a log Kow of -0.95(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this estimated Koc value suggests that glycidol is expected to have very high mobility in soil.
